issue.title: [BUG]  the replica auto balance displayed in the volume details different from the configuration and UI genreal

labels.name: require/backport
labels.description: Require backport. Only used when the specific versions to backport have not been definied.

issue.body:
version：v1.4.4
platform：arm64
install：helmv3


values.yaml
```yaml
...
defaultSettings:
  backupTarget: ~
  backupTargetCredentialSecret: ~
  allowRecurringJobWhileVolumeDetached: ~
  createDefaultDiskLabeledNodes: ~
  defaultDataPath: /opt/longhorn
  defaultDataLocality: ~
  replicaSoftAntiAffinity: ~
  replicaAutoBalance: "best-effort"
...
```

New environment installation
in pvc info
![image](https://github.com/longhorn/longhorn/assets/35453327/f8070161-6c43-47a1-b683-2b0b2baaba79)
in genreal
![image](https://github.com/longhorn/longhorn/assets/35453327/508ba500-e748-4a44-b5ec-bde7289ec69c)

sc info
```yaml
Name:            longhorn
IsDefaultClass:  Yes
Annotations:     longhorn.io/last-applied-configmap=kind: StorageClass
apiVersion: storage.k8s.io/v1
metadata:
  name: longhorn
  annotations:
    storageclass.kubernetes.io/is-default-class: "true"
provisioner: driver.longhorn.io
allowVolumeExpansion: true
reclaimPolicy: "Delete"
volumeBindingMode: Immediate
parameters:
  numberOfReplicas: "2"
  staleReplicaTimeout: "30"
  fromBackup: ""
  fsType: "ext4"
  dataLocality: "best-effort"
,storageclass.kubernetes.io/is-default-class=true
Provisioner:           driver.longhorn.io
Parameters:            dataLocality=best-effort,fromBackup=,fsType=ext4,numberOfReplicas=2,staleReplicaTimeout=30
AllowVolumeExpansion:  True
MountOptions:          <none>
ReclaimPolicy:         Delete
VolumeBindingMode:     Immediate
Events:                <none>

```

comment.body:
> When a volume is created without specifying Replica Auto Balance, Longhorn will automatically set to ignored to inherit from the global setting.

IIf I want it to be `best-effort by` default without specifying Replica Auto Balance , how do I do that

labels.name: require/backport
labels.description: Require backport. Only used when the specific versions to backport have not been definied.

issue.body:
version：v1.4.4
platform：arm64
install：helmv3


values.yaml
```yaml
...
defaultSettings:
  backupTarget: ~
  backupTargetCredentialSecret: ~
  allowRecurringJobWhileVolumeDetached: ~
  createDefaultDiskLabeledNodes: ~
  defaultDataPath: /opt/longhorn
  defaultDataLocality: ~
  replicaSoftAntiAffinity: ~
  replicaAutoBalance: "best-effort"
...
```

New environment installation
in pvc info
![image](https://github.com/longhorn/longhorn/assets/35453327/f8070161-6c43-47a1-b683-2b0b2baaba79)
in genreal
![image](https://github.com/longhorn/longhorn/assets/35453327/508ba500-e748-4a44-b5ec-bde7289ec69c)

sc info
```yaml
Name:            longhorn
IsDefaultClass:  Yes
Annotations:     longhorn.io/last-applied-configmap=kind: StorageClass
apiVersion: storage.k8s.io/v1
metadata:
  name: longhorn
  annotations:
    storageclass.kubernetes.io/is-default-class: "true"
provisioner: driver.longhorn.io
allowVolumeExpansion: true
reclaimPolicy: "Delete"
volumeBindingMode: Immediate
parameters:
  numberOfReplicas: "2"
  staleReplicaTimeout: "30"
  fromBackup: ""
  fsType: "ext4"
  dataLocality: "best-effort"
,storageclass.kubernetes.io/is-default-class=true
Provisioner:           driver.longhorn.io
Parameters:            dataLocality=best-effort,fromBackup=,fsType=ext4,numberOfReplicas=2,staleReplicaTimeout=30
AllowVolumeExpansion:  True
MountOptions:          <none>
ReclaimPolicy:         Delete
VolumeBindingMode:     Immediate
Events:                <none>

```

comment.body:
This is the default behavior. Check https://longhorn.io/docs/1.4.4/references/settings/#replica-auto-balance cc @c3y1huang 

> ignored. This is the default option that instructs Longhorn to inherit from the global setting.

issue.title: [BACKPORT][v1.5.2][IMPROVEMENT] High memory consumption of longhorn-manager pods since Longhorn v1.5

labels.name: priority/0
labels.description: Must be fixed in this release (managed by PO)

labels.name: kind/improvement
labels.description: Request for improvement of existing function

labels.name: require/backport
labels.description: Require backport. Only used when the specific versions to backport have not been definied.

issue.body: backport https://github.com/longhorn/longhorn/issues/6936

comment.body:
> it seems the memory usage of 1.5.x-head is higher than 1.4.x-head. 

This is expected.


- Memory usage
  - v1.5.x < v1.5.0/v1.5.0 (because of the trebled caches)
  - v1.4.x < v1.5.x (because of the merge of multiple services)

comment.body:
Thanks, @derekbit .

I was just confused about what @yangchiu reported. From his test summary, it seems the memory usage of 1.5.x-head is higher than 1.4.x-head. However, the test we wanted should be comparing 1.5.x-head with 1.5.1.  @yangchiu can you confirm this?

issue.title: [BACKPORT][v1.5.2][BUG] Orphan snapshot attachment tickets prevent volume from detaching
issue.body: backport https://github.com/longhorn/longhorn/issues/6652

comment.body:
Hi @ejweber,

I tested the v1.4.3 to v1.5.x snacerio by modify longhorn-manager/version to v1.5.2 from [a67dc7](https://github.com/longhorn/longhorn-manager/commit/a67dc7fb6d97d16a86ec15c93489c9cd4e3f5966) to build image and test [passed](https://github.com/longhorn/longhorn/issues/6653#issuecomment-1780699625)

While perform v1.5.2-rc1 release testing, I find that when upgrade v1.4.4(have volume with workload) to v1.5.2-rc1, the upgrade process will fail because longhorn-manager will CrashLoopBackOff due to `volumeattachments.longhorn.io` fatal error
```
time="2023-10-27T08:35:07Z" level=fatal msg="Error starting manager: upgrade resources failed: volumeattachments.longhorn.io \"pvc-7a0a31ef-0a34-4ee7-9562-43a7db1e7802\" is invalid: metadata.resourceVersion: Invalid value: 0x0: must be specified for an update" func=app.DaemonCmd.func1 file="daemon.go:83"
```

I can not generate support bundle because longhorn-manager not ready and below are related information for your reference

<details>
  <summary>volumeattachments.longhorn.io created after upgrade</summary>
  

  ```yaml
  root@ip-172-31-47-207:/home/ubuntu# k get volumeattachments.longhorn.io -n longhorn-system -o yaml
apiVersion: v1
items:
- apiVersion: longhorn.io/v1beta2
  kind: VolumeAttachment
  metadata:
    creationTimestamp: "2023-10-27T08:18:30Z"
    finalizers:
    - longhorn.io
    generation: 1
    labels:
      longhornvolume: pvc-7a0a31ef-0a34-4ee7-9562-43a7db1e7802
    name: pvc-7a0a31ef-0a34-4ee7-9562-43a7db1e7802
    namespace: longhorn-system
    ownerReferences:
    - apiVersion: longhorn.io/v1beta2
      kind: Volume
      name: pvc-7a0a31ef-0a34-4ee7-9562-43a7db1e7802
      uid: db89e6d5-854e-4d1b-9ef8-ba41d4613fc8
    resourceVersion: "3002"
    uid: 5f7a6c31-27ae-4e3c-9797-47398b8f643c
  spec:
    attachmentTickets:
      csi-bc2f093b83b08716700629ee0a81e7119b8fe8e43dfaddf8684863d91fc5afca:
        generation: 0
        id: csi-bc2f093b83b08716700629ee0a81e7119b8fe8e43dfaddf8684863d91fc5afca
        nodeID: ip-172-31-34-145
        parameters:
          disableFrontend: "false"
        type: csi-attacher
    volume: pvc-7a0a31ef-0a34-4ee7-9562-43a7db1e7802
kind: List
metadata:
  resourceVersion: ""
  ```
</details>

<details>
  <summary>longhorn manager log</summary>
  

  ```bash
  root@ip-172-31-47-207:/home/ubuntu# k logs longhorn-manager-b8qmw -n longhorn-system
W1027 08:35:03.768361       1 client_config.go:618] Neither --kubeconfig nor --master was specified.  Using the inClusterConfig.  This might not work.

time="2023-10-27T08:35:03Z" level=info msg="Active TLS secret longhorn-webhook-tls (ver=1052) (count 2): map[listener.cattle.io/cn-longhorn-admission-webhook.longhor-59584d:longhorn-admission-webhook.longhorn-system.svc listener.cattle.io/cn-longhorn-conversion-webhook.longho-6a0089:longhorn-conversion-webhook.longhorn-system.svc listener.cattle.io/fingerprint:SHA1=94F5CA1CCF7431CDC4F8AB60706BBE889EBD6207]" func="memory.(*memory).Update" file="memory.go:42"
 ```

labels.name: priority/0
labels.description: Must be fixed in this release (managed by PO)

labels.name: kind/improvement
labels.description: Request for improvement of existing function

labels.name: require/backport
labels.description: Require backport. Only used when the specific versions to backport have not been definied.

issue.body: backport https://github.com/longhorn/longhorn/issues/6936

comment.body:
Verified passed on v1.5.x-head (longhorn-manager 2d14e40).

Created 1000 volumes and compare `v1.4.x-head` with `v1.5.x-head`, increasing memory usage of longhorn manager can be observed:

- `v1.4.xhead`:
```
kubectl -n longhorn-system top pods --sort-by=memory
NAME                                                  CPU(cores)   MEMORY(bytes)   
longhorn-manager-hcddd                                883m         174Mi           
longhorn-manager-9zrjs                                1207m        144Mi           
longhorn-manager-66sjq                                1042m        136Mi         
```

- `v1.5.x-head`:
```
kubectl -n longhorn-system top pods --sort-by=memory
NAME                                                CPU(cores)   MEMORY(bytes)   
longhorn-manager-84fz6                              320m         461Mi           
longhorn-manager-l9zx5                              4m           400Mi           
longhorn-manager-twt78                              6m           364Mi    
```

issue.title: [IMPROVEMENT] Review and simplify longhorn component image build

labels.name: priority/0
labels.description: Must be fixed in this release (managed by PO)

labels.name: area/package
labels.description: Package related like build, dependency management, etc

labels.name: kind/improvement
labels.description: Request for improvement of existing function

issue.body:
## Is your improvement request related to a feature? Please describe (👍 if you like this request)

Need to review dockerfile and dockerfile.dapper of each component to clean up or simplify the build flow and content inside; one of the examples is https://github.com/longhorn/longhorn-instance-manager/blob/master/Dockerfile.dapper#L27-L61, the tgt and liblonghorn build are unnecessary in build image since they are already in https://github.com/longhorn/longhorn-instance-manager/blob/master/package/Dockerfile

## Describe the solution you'd like

A clear and concise description of what you want to happen.

## Describe alternatives you've considered

A clear and concise description of any alternative solutions or features you've considered.

## Additional context

Add any other context or screenshots about the feature request here.

cc @longhorn/dev

comment.body:
Hi @innobead 
I found we check grpc generated code in longhorn-engine but not in longhorn-instance-manager
- longhorn-engine: https://github.com/longhorn/longhorn-engine/blob/master/scripts/prebuild
- longhorn-instance-manager: https://github.com/longhorn/longhorn-instance-manager/tree/master/scripts
I think this is to prevent somebody from forgetting to regenerated the code after updating the proto.

issue.body:
## Is your improvement request related to a feature? Please describe (👍 if you like this request)

To reduce the cross interference between v1 and v2 volumes, handling v1 and v2 volumes in separate pods is better. 
The ticket aims to create instance-managers for v1 and v2 volumes respectively.

issue.title: [BUG] High CPU usage on one node.

labels.name: area/instance-manager
labels.description: Longhorn instance manager (interface between control and data plane)

labels.name: priority/0
labels.description: Must be fixed in this release (managed by PO)

issue.body:
## Describe the bug (🐛 if you encounter this issue)

We have a cluster with 3 worker nodes running 3 environments + Loki + Prometheus + Grafana + Minio, one of the servers have high cpu usage from the Instance manager, it basically consumes over 1 CPU when in the other nodes it consumes < 100m.

We also detected the following log in the instance manager pod

`
[longhorn-instance-manager] time="2023-08-23T02:22:11Z" level=error msg="Failed to receive next item in process watch" error="rpc error: code = Unavailable desc = keepalive ping failed to receive ACK within timeout"
`
## To Reproduce

N/A

## Expected behavior

All nodes behave in the same maner and consume a reasonable amount of CPU

## Support bundle for troubleshooting

[supportbundle_a1cc04ad-a7b1-44c1-a239-b8a956ed43fc_2023-08-23T02-28-23Z.zip](https://github.com/longhorn/longhorn/files/12414560/supportbundle_a1cc04ad-a7b1-44c1-a239-b8a956ed43fc_2023-08-23T02-28-23Z.zip)


## Environment

 - Longhorn version: v1.5.1
 - Installation method (e.g. Rancher Catalog App/Helm/Kubectl): Kubectl
 - Kubernetes distro (e.g. RKE/K3s/EKS/OpenShift) and version: K8 1.28
   - Number of management node in the cluster: 1
   - Number of worker node in the cluster: 3
 - Node config
   - OS type and version: CentOS 7
   - Kernel version: 3.10.0-1160.95.1.el7.x86_64
   - CPU per node: 3
   - Memory per node: 16g
   - Disk type(e.g. SSD/NVMe/HDD): ssd
   - Network bandwidth between the nodes: 
 - Underlying Infrastructure (e.g. on AWS/GCE, EKS/GKE, VMWare/KVM, Baremetal): Azure VM
 - Number of Longhorn volumes in the cluster: 18

## Additional context

Some additional Info:

kubectl top po
instance-manager-5b4f8e9293673b61843ec90d86572317                 62m          466Mi
instance-manager-cd6e4595e2282572b9b2580deb2b9024                 1163m        460Mi
instance-manager-de8c80e633236a07311ae611a2e7adc8                 87m          866Mi

This is our Grafana monitor showing CPU usage (note that 90% of this CPU usage comes from one node):

![image](https://github.com/longhorn/longhorn/assets/881660/5c44d3e5-82cf-43ab-ac6b-7071214d216c)


## Workaround

Before the release v1.5.2, please refer to the steps and temporary longhorn-instance-manager with the fix in https://github.com/longhorn/longhorn/issues/6645#issuecomment-1756807554.

comment.body:
@m3nax 
Thank you for the update. The update makes us more confident for the fix.

pull_request.title: Fix chart labels
pull_request.body:
Switch the `app` label key to the well known `app.kubernetes.io/component` key instead. This helps other applications (like cilium hubble) identify the Pods easier. More information about the label can be found here: https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/labels-annotations-taints/#app-kubernetes-io-component

I've remove the `app:` label from the tls-secret, as I felt like it did not serve a purpose and all important labels are already added by the helper script.

I was unable to find any reference to this label in the application code (but that said, I'm not very familiar with the application code).

This is a replacement for PR #6974 where I messed up the label key name.

repo.name: longhorn
repo.description: Cloud-Native distributed storage built on and for Kubernetes

repo.name: longhorn
repo.description: Cloud-Native distributed storage built on and for Kubernetes

pull_request.title: Fix app name label
pull_request.body:
According to Kubernetes docs, it's customary to use app.kubernetes.io/name instead of just app
(https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/labels-annotations-taints/#app-kubernetes-io-name). This helps other tools (like cilium hubble) easier identify the workloads on the cluster.

repo.name: longhorn
repo.description: Cloud-Native distributed storage built on and for Kubernetes

repo.description: Cloud-Native distributed storage built on and for Kubernetes

issue.title: Fix app name label
issue.body:
According to Kubernetes docs, it's customary to use app.kubernetes.io/name instead of just app
(https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/labels-annotations-taints/#app-kubernetes-io-name). This helps other tools (like cilium hubble) easier identify the workloads on the cluster.

comment.body: Actually, I messed this up. I'll start again using the correct labels and I noticed there are already several helper scripts to help with this as well.

issue.title: Fix app name label
issue.body:
According to Kubernetes docs, it's customary to use app.kubernetes.io/name instead of just app
(https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/labels-annotations-taints/#app-kubernetes-io-name). This helps other tools (like cilium hubble) easier identify the workloads on the cluster.

comment.body:
Good point, I made an additional check and found a few places where I forgot to fix it and some scripts that are using those. Adding the commits now.

I did not found any reference to the label key "app" in the actual longhorn code, but I did come across some examples and code in `deploy` that is using the app key. I'll modify those as well.

issue.title: [BUG] high cpu usage retry loop

labels.name: require/backport
labels.description: Require backport. Only used when the specific versions to backport have not been definied.

issue.body:
the longhorn-manager ate up 1 cpu with this repeating log message:

```
...
2023-10-24 08:30:30.282Z,longhorn-manager-2g75n,longhorn-manager,"2:00 time="2023-10-24T06:30:30Z" level=error msg="Max retry period 24h0m0s reached in exponential backoff timer" backup=backup-f2ffba8518e446ca controller=longhorn-backup node=srv1"
2023-10-24 08:30:30.282Z,longhorn-manager-2g75n,longhorn-manager,"2:00 time="2023-10-24T06:30:30Z" level=error msg="Max retry period 24h0m0s reached in exponential backoff timer" backup=backup-f2ffba8518e446ca controller=longhorn-backup node=srv1"
2023-10-24 08:30:30.282Z,longhorn-manager-2g75n,longhorn-manager,"2:00 time="2023-10-24T06:30:30Z" level=error msg="Max retry period 24h0m0s reached in exponential backoff timer" backup=backup-f2ffba8518e446ca controller=longhorn-backup node=srv1"
2023-10-24 08:30:30.282Z,longhorn-manager-2g75n,longhorn-manager,"2:00 time="2023-10-24T06:30:30Z" level=error msg="Max retry period 24h0m0s reached in exponential backoff timer" backup=backup-f2ffba8518e446ca controller=longhorn-backup node=srv1"
...
```

it could be that it was caused by a taint NoSchedule on that node. nevertheless it should sleep betweed the retries.

comment.body:
No sure if it is related to https://github.com/longhorn/longhorn/issues/4255.
You can upgrade Longhorn v1.4.4 and see if all work well.

issue.title: [BUG] Backing Image Data Inconsistency if it's Exported from a Backing Image Backed Volume

labels.name: priority/0
labels.description: Must be fixed in this release (managed by PO)

labels.name: require/backport
labels.description: Require backport. Only used when the specific versions to backport have not been definied.

issue.body:
## Describe the bug (🐛 if you encounter this issue)
The volume encounters a data integrity issue, if it's from a backing image, and such backing image is exported by a volume backed by another backing image.

## To Reproduce
1. Preparing a Harvester v1.2.0-head cluster (for using volume as an OS root disk)
2. Uploading Ubuntu jammy cloud image ([latest version](https://cloud-images.ubuntu.com/jammy/current/jammy-server-cloudimg-amd64.img)), **img1**
3. Creating volume **vol1** from **img1**
4. Creating a VM with **vol1** as the root disk, and writing some data
5. Issuing sync on filesystem, e.q. `$ sudo sync`
6. Stopping VM, and waiting until **vol1** is completely detached
7. Exporting **vol1** as **img2**
8. Creating  **vol2** from **img2**
9. Comparing data content between **vol1** and **vol2**, the data is inconsistent
10. Running fsck on **vol2**, fsck will report filesystem errors and require data repair

## Expected behavior
The data of **vol1** and **vol2** should be consistent.

## Support bundle for troubleshooting
[supportbundle_066aa8ed-a12b-4ccc-971c-59404ee44cd4_2023-10-16T07-46-44Z.zip](https://github.com/longhorn/longhorn/files/12913647/supportbundle_066aa8ed-a12b-4ccc-971c-59404ee44cd4_2023-10-16T07-46-44Z.zip)

## Environment

<!-- Suggest checking the doc of the best practices of using Longhorn. [here](https://longhorn.io/docs/1.5.1/best-practices)-->
 - Longhorn version: v1.4.3
 - Harvester version: v1.2.0-head
 - Number of Longhorn volumes in the cluster: 2
 - Impacted Longhorn resources:
   - Volume names: pvc-b8bd9013-e8e9-449d-9c25-6c6c0824d0b3, pvc-de64dd95-b0c1-4ce9-864a-88d38e06d9d3

## Additional context

<!--Add any other context about the problem here.-->
- If **vol1** is not backed by backing image, there is no data inconsistency found between **vol1** and **vol2**
- A single node Harvester cluster should be enough to reproduce this issue

comment.body:
Some observations with the following steps:
1. Preparing a Harvester v1.2.0-head single node cluster (for using volume as an OS root disk)
2. Uploading Ubuntu jammy cloud image ([latest version](https://cloud-images.ubuntu.com/jammy/current/jammy-server-cloudimg-amd64.img)), **img1** with replica number is 1
3. Checking data usage of **img1** (mapped to `bi default-image-s9rfj`), which is `640MB` ![data_usage_origin_img](https://github.com/longhorn/longhorn/assets/19387129/c79d04d3-cb9e-4383-8a07-19212c74de01)
4. Creating volume **os-vol** (mapped to `volume pvc-c3b1a434-86ee-453b-afc7-a52fe113c059`) from **img1** with claim size 10GB
5. Creating a VM with  **os-vol** as the root disk
6. Stopping VM, and waiting until **os-vol** is completely detached
7. Exporting **os-vol** as **os-vol.img** (mapped to `bi default-image-j8ghr`) with replica number is 1
8. Checking replica data usage of **os-vol**, which is `523MB` ![data_usage_os_vol](https://github.com/longhorn/longhorn/assets/19387129/bd756b83-c28d-4336-9512-4789f8a8ef23)
9. Checking data usage of **os-vol.img**, which is `2507MB` ![data_usage_os_vol_img](https://github.com/longhorn/longhorn/assets/19387129/ac8aa9d4-1620-4ba0-a5c5-2493a50fe1b3)
     - For the data usage, **os-vol.img**(2507MB) is much greater than the summation of **img1**(640MB) and **os-vol**(523MB)
     - The **os-vol.img**'s data usage shouldn't be greater than the summation of **img1**'s and **os-vol**'s ?
10. Creating volume **copy-vol** from **os-vol.img** with claim size 10GB
11. Comparing data content between **os-vol** and **copy-vol** with `$cmp -l os-vol copy-vol`
12. From the compare result [cmp.log](https://github.com/longhorn/longhorn/files/13184929/cmp.log), there are several continuous byte ranges overwritten with zero in the synthetic volume, **copy-vol**

Thanks
